title: What does CSS stand for and what is its primary use?
content: CSS stands for Cascading Style Sheets. It is primarily used to separate web page content (HTML) from its visual presentation (styling), enabling consistent and maintainable design across pages.
explanation: CSS allows developers to control layout, colors, fonts, and responsiveness without altering HTML structure, promoting separation of concerns.
sampleAnswers: CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) is used to style HTML elements—controlling layout, colors, fonts, spacing, and responsive behavior.
Its primary purpose is to decouple content from presentation, making websites easier to maintain and style consistently.

title: How do you include CSS in your HTML document?
content: There are four ways to include CSS: inline styles, embedded (internal) styles in a `<style>` tag, external stylesheets via `<link>`, and imported styles using `@import`.
explanation: External stylesheets are preferred for maintainability and caching. Inline styles have highest specificity but hurt reusability.

options.text: CSS cannot be included in HTML

title: Can you explain the difference between class and ID selectors?
content: Class selectors (`.class`) can be reused on multiple elements. ID selectors (`#id`) should be unique to a single element per page.
explanation: IDs have higher specificity than classes. While HTML allows duplicate IDs, it’s invalid and breaks accessibility and JavaScript.

options.text: Class is for one element; ID is for many
Class can be reused; ID should be unique
ID selectors are faster in all browsers

title: What are pseudo-classes in CSS?
content: Pseudo-classes (e.g., `:hover`, `:focus`, `:nth-child`) style elements based on state, position, or user interaction—not just tag/class/ID.
explanation: Pseudo-classes enable dynamic styling without JavaScript—e.g., `:hover` for interactivity, `:disabled` for form states, `:nth-child` for alternating rows.
sampleAnswers: Pseudo-classes like `:hover`, `:focus`, and `:nth-child` let you style elements based on their state or position in the DOM tree.
They are essential for interactive UIs—e.g., changing button color on hover or styling every odd table row.

title: Describe how to implement a CSS reset and why it is useful.
content: A CSS reset (or normalize) removes default browser styles (margins, paddings, font sizes) to ensure consistent rendering across browsers.
explanation: Browsers apply default styles differently. A reset (like Eric Meyer’s) or normalize.css creates a predictable baseline for styling.
sampleAnswers: A CSS reset removes default margins, paddings, and styles so your design looks consistent across all browsers.
Popular options include `normalize.css` (preserves useful defaults) or a full reset (strips all defaults).

title: How do you select elements by attribute in CSS?
content: Use attribute selectors like `[attr]`, `[attr=value]`, `[attr^=value]`, or `[attr$=value]` to target elements based on HTML attributes.
explanation: Attribute selectors are powerful for targeting form inputs, links, or custom data attributes without adding classes.

options.text: `[href]` selects elements with an href attribute

title: What is a pseudo-element, and what are they used for?
content: Pseudo-elements (`::before`, `::after`, `::first-line`, etc.) style parts of an element that aren’t real HTML nodes.
explanation: `::before` and `::after` insert generated content for icons, quotes, or decorative elements without extra HTML.
sampleAnswers: Pseudo-elements like `::before` and `::after` let you insert and style content before/after an element’s actual content.
Common uses: adding icons to links, creating custom checkboxes, or clearing floats with `::after { content: ''; clear: both; }`.

title: Explain the difference between the child combinator and the descendant combinator.
content: Child combinator (`>`) selects direct children only. Descendant combinator (space) selects all nested descendants.
explanation:
`div > p` matches only `

` directly inside `

`. `div p` matches any `

` nested anywhere inside `

`.

options.text: `>` selects direct children; space selects all descendants

title: How would you select all direct children elements of a particular type?
content: Use the child combinator: `parent > child`. Example: `ul > li` selects only `<li>` that are direct children of `<ul>`.
explanation: This avoids styling nested grandchildren, giving precise control over list or layout structures.
sampleAnswers: Use `ul > li` to select only direct `<li>` children of a `<ul>`, ignoring nested list items.
The `>` combinator ensures you only target immediate children, not deeper descendants.

title: What are the universal selector and the sibling combinator, and when would you use them?
content: Universal selector (`*`) matches all elements. Sibling combinator (`+`) matches an element immediately after another.
explanation: Use `*` for resets; use `+` for styling elements that follow a specific sibling (e.g., `h2 + p` for paragraphs after headings).

options.text: `*` selects all elements; `+` selects immediate next sibling
`*` is for classes; `+` is for IDs

title: What is the CSS Box Model?
content: The Box Model describes an element’s structure: content, padding, border, and margin. Total width = content + padding + border + margin.
explanation: Understanding the box model is essential for accurate layout. `box-sizing: border-box` includes padding/border in width/height.
sampleAnswers: The CSS Box Model consists of content, padding, border, and margin. By default, width/height apply only to content.
Using `box-sizing: border-box` makes width include padding and border, simplifying responsive layouts.

title: Explain margin collapsing.
content: Margin collapsing occurs when vertical margins of adjacent or nested block elements combine into a single margin (the larger one).
explanation: Only vertical margins collapse. Prevent it with borders, padding, flex/grid, or `overflow: hidden`.
sampleAnswers: When two vertical margins touch, they collapse into the larger margin—e.g., a 20px and 30px margin become 30px.
To prevent collapsing, add a border, padding, or use a flex/grid container between the elements.

title: What are the different values for the box-sizing property and what do they do?
content: `content-box` (default): width/height = content only. `border-box`: width/height = content + padding + border.
explanation: `border-box` is preferred in modern CSS because it makes sizing predictable when padding/border are added.

title: How do you center a block element with CSS?
content: Horizontally: `margin: 0 auto` (with width). Vertically: use Flexbox (`align-items: center`) or Grid (`place-items: center`).
explanation: Modern centering uses Flexbox or Grid. Legacy methods include absolute positioning with transforms.
sampleAnswers: Horizontally: `.box { width: 50%; margin: 0 auto; }`. Vertically: `.container { display: flex; align-items: center; justify-content: center; }`
CSS Grid: `.container { display: grid; place-items: center; }` centers both horizontally and vertically.

title: What is the difference between block, inline, and inline-block elements?
content: Block: full width, line break. Inline: flows in text, no width/height. Inline-block: flows inline but accepts width/height/padding.
explanation: `<div>` is block; `<span>` is inline; `inline-block` is used for navigation menus or icon grids.

options.text: Block: full width, line break; Inline: no width/height; Inline-block: inline with box model
